title: Lalkul Whitepaper V0
subtitle: A Representation Framework for Cardano Governance

sections.title: Introduction and Purpose
content: The Lalkul DRep initiative was established to address key challenges within Cardano’s governance model as it transitions into the Voltaire phase. Under the CIP-1694 governance framework, Delegated Representatives (DReps) play a critical role in decision-making on behalf of the Cardano community.

content.subtitle: Cardano Governance Pillars
items: Intersect: A member-based organization tasked with overseeing Cardano's code development.
On-chain governance: Involves decision-making by Delegated Representatives (DReps), Stake Pool Operators (SPOs), and a Constitutional Committee (CC).
The Constitution: Final version ratified during a workshop in Argentina in December, 2024.

content.subtitle: DRep Responsibilities
items: Evaluating proposals related to protocol upgrades, staking, infrastructure improvements, and other governance actions.
Making informed decisions on behalf of ADA holders, who delegate their voting power to them.
Engaging with the community to understand its priorities and concerns.

content.subtitle: Challenges
items: Broad skill requirements: The complex and technical nature of many governance proposals requires expertise in multiple domains, which is difficult for a single DRep to possess.
Lack of a structured framework: Current DRep systems lack a comprehensive structure that ensures effective decision-making, accountability, and community engagement.

content: The Lalkul DRep initiative provides a solution by introducing a team-managed DRep approach grounded in Sociocratic Pluralism and the principles of sociocracy. This model leverages the expertise of multiple community members through a structured, circle-based governance system.

content.subtitle: Key Benefits
items: Specialized Expertise: Each subcircle can focus on a specific domain (e.g., Infrastructure, Applications, Open topics), ensuring decisions are made by those with relevant knowledge.
Inclusive Decision-Making: Using a consent-based model, the team can incorporate multiple perspectives and ensure that decisions are not dominated by a single individual.
Clear Accountability: The circle structure promotes transparency, as all decision-making processes are documented and shared with the community.

content.subtitle: Vision, Mission, and Aim
items: Vision: Lalkul seeks to illuminate an enlightened pathway for decentralized governance.
Mission: To create and adopt a framework for a collective Cardano DRep committed to improving decentralized governance.
Aim: Develop and model exceptional Delegated Representation by building an inclusive and resilient community, utilizing prosocial principles of democracy, pluralism, and sociocracy.

subsections.title: Sociocratic Principles
items: Peer-to-Peer Circles: Decisions are made within circles, which represent teams of people with specific expertise. Each circle has autonomy over its domain but is interlinked with other circles.

Consent-Based Decision-Making: Decisions are made when no one has reasoned objections. This approach ensures decisions are not blocked by minor disagreements but are 'good enough for now and safe to try.'
Feedback Loops: Continuous feedback is collected to evaluate decisions, ensuring they evolve over time and are refined based on community input.
Role Rotation: Leadership roles within each circle are rotated periodically, ensuring that no individual dominates decision-making and fresh perspectives are brought into leadership positions.

subsections.title: Coordinating Circle: Lalkul DRep
content: The coordinating circle serves as the central authority for the Lalkul DRep initiative. It is responsible for coordinating the activities of subcircles, overseeing key governance decisions, and ensuring alignment with the overall vision and mission of the Lalkul DRep.

content.subtitle: Responsibilities
items: Final decision-making accountability on governance proposals.
Coordination of subcircles, ensuring that each circle is functioning effectively and is aligned with Lalkul’s goals.
Engagement with the broader Cardano community, gathering feedback and ensuring transparency in governance.

content.subtitle: Key Roles
items: Leader: Guides the strategic direction of Lalkul DRep and ensures that subcircles align with the overall mission.
Facilitator: Oversees meetings and ensures smooth discussions, helping guide the consent-based decision-making process.
Secretary: Keeps detailed meeting minutes, documents decisions, and ensures all records are transparent and accessible to the community.
Delegate(s): Represent the subcircles in the parent circle, ensuring that communication flows between the circles and bringing important proposals back to the parent circle for final decisions.

subsections.title: Role Definitions
content: The governance structure relies on clearly defined roles to ensure smooth operations and accountability.

content.subtitle: Roles
items: Leader: Sets the strategic direction for the circle and ensures alignment with the mission and objectives.
Facilitator: Guides discussions, ensures meetings run smoothly, and helps the circle reach consent.
Secretary: Documents meetings, tracks action items, and ensures transparency by maintaining records.
Delegate: Represents the subcircle in the parent circle and serves as a communication bridge between circles.

Member: Not all members will have one of the above roles. If there are enough members in a circle, some members will just be members. All members’ consent is needed to pass a decision within that circle.

content.subtitle: Role Rotation
items: All roles within the circle are rotated periodically to prevent stagnation and encourage leadership development. The rotation time frame can be decided by each subcircle but is recommended to start with no more than 1 year terms for this first iteration.

subsections.title: Domain Circles
content: Each domain circle is responsible for handling governance decisions related to specific domains of expertise. By focusing on different aspects of Cardano’s ecosystem, each subcircle can apply specialized knowledge to governance proposals.
As we are still growing we found it beneficial to combine the 4 traditional sociocratic circle roles into two essential roles for the subcircles: Facilitator and Leader, Secretary and Delegate.
The subcircle will be in charge of recommending a vote with justification to the parent circle.

items.name: Infrastructure Circle
items.focus: Governance decisions related to Cardano’s infrastructure, such as protocol upgrades, staking mechanisms, and network improvements.
items.targetMembers: Blockchain developers, protocol experts, infrastructure-focused SPOs.

items.name: Applications Circle
items.focus: Decisions related to decentralized applications (DApps), DeFi protocols, and other Cardano-based solutions.
items.targetMembers: Entrepreneurs, DApp developers, product managers, and DeFi experts.

items.name: Open Circle
items.focus: Any governance actions that do not fit into the other subcircles or exploratory governance topics. This circle is also in charge of onboarding new members and creating other domain circles.
items.targetMembers: Cardano community members, technical and non-technical participants, those interested in governance processes.

items.name: Policy Circle (non-voting)
items.focus: To provide the DRep with policies and advice on structure, decision-making processes, voting mechanisms, etc.
items.targetMembers: Advisors, Industry leaders, Constitutional Committee members, SPOs.

content.subtitle: Subcircle Autonomy
items: Each subcircle has the authority to make decisions within its domain but must ensure that major decisions align with the broader objectives of Lalkul DRep.

Subcircles meet weekly or bi-weekly, depending on their activity level, and submit reports to the parent circle. The leader and representative are responsible for updating the parent circle on key decisions and progress.

content.subtitle: Collaboration and Communication
items: Regular calls (biweekly as a default for the early phase, although could be more or less frequent as needed) for the greater DRep circles.
Breakout sessions for each domain circle to discuss their processes, propose improvements, and align on their ongoing responsibilities.
Opportunities to share updates and insights across circles to improve governance coordination and accountability.

subsections.title: Assignment to Domain Circles
items: Governance actions are assigned to specific domain circles based on their relevance and scope.
Assignments must be made at least X amount of time before votes are due to allow adequate time for deliberation and review.
If no clear domain circle is applicable, proposals are temporarily assigned to the most relevant circle or distributed randomly in the first iteration.
If a governance action requires multi-disciplinary input, the assigned domain circles join to form a greater circle for collaborative review.

subsections.title: Decision-making within Domain Circles
items: Proposal Review: Members analyze the proposal’s relevance, impact, and alignment with governance principles.
Discussion and Feedback: Members discuss the proposal in rounds, share perspectives, and address objections or concerns collaboratively.
Consent-Based Approval: Decisions are reached using consent-based decision-making unless substantial objections arise. Any objections must be resolved before finalizing.
Justification: Approved decisions include a written justification to ensure transparency and provide context for the broader community.
Escalation: Proposals with unresolved objections or requiring broader input are escalated to the coordinating circle.

subsections.title: Coordinating Circle Voting Process
items: Voting Process: The Lalkul DRep casts the vote. In Phase 1, the domain circle leader (or another member if the leader is unavailable) joins the voting member online to review and align before casting the vote via governance tools (govtools).
Transparency: After voting, the Lalkul DRep publishes a report detailing the proposal, rationale, and voting outcome on governance tools and social channels.

subsections.title: Emergency Decision Handling
items: Emergency Meeting: The coordinating circle holds a meeting with at least one member of the relevant domain circle present.
No Representation, No Vote: If no meeting or representation occurs in time, no vote is cast, prioritizing integrity over expediency.

subsections.title: Onboarding Process
items: Guest Participation: New members begin as guests, observing discussions and subcircle meetings. Guests do not have voting power but are encouraged to contribute to conversations and learn governance processes.
Becoming a Full Member: Guests may apply for full membership after meeting proof of life (PoL) and attendance requirements. Full membership is granted through a consent-based approval process.
Ongoing Participation: Full members are expected to actively participate. Non-participation may result in reverting to guest status.

subsections.title: Mentorship Opportunities
items: New Member Mentorship: Role-specific guidance and shadowing opportunities.
Leadership Mentorship: Outgoing leaders mentor successors during role rotations.
External Mentorship for Other dReps: Workshops, guidance, and ongoing support for other dReps adopting the framework.

subsections.title: Future Vision: The Lalkul Alliance
items: Backed by Photrek: Lalkul is supported by Photrek, providing tools and governance expertise.
Exploring Partnerships: Combining offerings with other organizations.
Empowering Other dReps: Offering tools and resources to replicate and adapt the Lalkul model.

subsections.title: Incentives and Recognition
items: Personal Impact: Members shape governance frameworks.
Recognition: Contributions acknowledged within the community.
Long-Term Investment: Positioning as key contributors to Cardano’s governance evolution.

sections.title: Adaptability and Customization
content: The Lalkul DRep framework is designed with flexibility in mind, allowing other dReps and organizations to tailor components to meet their unique needs. Key elements, such as decision-making processes, can be adjusted to align with specific goals, team dynamics, or operational requirements.

sections.title: Case Studies, Challenges and Lessons Learned

subsections.title: Challenges and Lessons Learned
items: Slow Decision-Making: Consent-based model led to delays. Solution: Established clearer timelines and escalation protocols.
Siloed Circles: Lack of communication caused fragmentation. Solution: Introduced biweekly calls with breakout sessions.
Onboarding Hurdles: New members struggled with tools and roles. Solution: Enhanced documentation and guest participation.
Sustaining Engagement: Unpaid roles led to challenges. Solution: Exploring compensation models.

subsections.title: Current Challenges and Call for Solutions
items: Balancing Consent and Efficiency: Streamlining consent-based decision-making while retaining inclusivity.
Retaining and Incentivizing Members: Sustainable incentive structures.
Scaling the Framework: Improving adoption process for other dReps.

sections.title: Conclusion and Call to Action
content: The Lalkul DRep framework provides a structured approach to effective decentralized representation within the Cardano ecosystem. By leveraging innovative decision-making processes, data-driven insights, and community engagement, this framework enhances transparency, accountability, and informed governance.

items: DRep and Sociocracy Training Programs: Gain skills to become an effective delegate representative.
Community Discussions & Workshops: Engage with other dReps, experts, and stakeholders.
Implementation Guides & Tools: Access resources to support the application of the Lalkul framework.
